awd_titl_txt: Constructing Metal-Carbon Multiple Bonds for Dehydrogenation and Dehydrocoupling Reactions Involving Volatile Hydrocarbons
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, the research team of Dr. Daniel Mindiola at the University of Pennsylvania is investigating the synthesis of earth-abundant (i.e., "base") metal complexes containing titanium, niobium, and vanadium. The complexes are studied for their ability to convert, catalytically and under mild conditions, alkanes into alkenes (i.e., compounds with carbon-carbon double bonds). Alkenes are building blocks in industry and are useful in the construction of polymers or other commodity chemicals indispensable to pharmaceuticals and petrochemicals. The research team is also investigating how to convert natural gas or volatile natural resources into liquid fuels since these are much easier to transport and store. The team is also investigating ways to convert nitrogen from our atmosphere into chemical fuels and important reagents such as ammonia or ammonium salts. This is done under mild conditions, also using well defined base metal catalysts. The catalysts that the team is synthesizing function under conditions that are milder (70-80 degree C) than cracking conditions used in the petrochemical industry (>800 degree C). Dr. Mindiola has been active with the ACS (American Chemical Society) serving as Chair of the ACS Scholars Program Subcommittee on Minority Affairs among many other activities to promote diversity in the physical sciences. He is actively involved in promoting science at the university level as well as in elementary and middle schools in the region by conducting demonstrations aimed at understanding natural resources such as nitrogen and natural gas.

Dr. Mindiola is investigating how base, early transition metals such as Ti, V, and Nb can promote the transfer dehydrogenation of volatile and linear hydrocarbons, selectively, into olefins and terminal olefins in the case of C4 and above. The research team is investigating mild conditions to perform such transformations by taking advantage of the reactive nature of metal-carbon multiple bonds. Through synthetic and mechanistic studies, the team is exploring optimization of conditions for higher catalytic turnover and selectivity. One particular reaction is the room temperature conversion of methane into an olefin using a well-defined Ti alkylidene or robust dinuclear systems. Dr. Mindiola is also exploring the catalytic room temperature conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia and ammonium salts using base metal niobium precursors that are simple to prepare and handle, and which have yielded intermediates that provide clues into how these systems bind, activate, and split the N-N triple bond. Dr. Mindiola is heavily involved with the American Chemical Society through committees and subcommittees aimed at promoting diversity in the physical sciences. He is also actively involved at the university level and in his community promoting science and educating society about natural gas and other greenhouse gases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our main theme is centered in the assembly of metal-ligand multiple bonds with some of the most electropositive metals of the transition block, not only to study their unusual electronic structure through a combination of structural, magnetic and spectroscopic studies, but also exploit their reactivity. Our proposed research program is based on a highly collaborative effort that brings together a battery of common and specialized techniques to facilitate cooperativity between subfields of chemistry such as spectroscopy and magnetism, mechanisms and new reaction pathways, and applications in catalysis, especially how one can convert alkanes that are typically burned, into more value-added materials with higher storage capacity. Our study is trying to find way to avoid burning of natural resources such as natural and shale gases and instead find alternative routes to selectively transforming these valuable reagents into more value-added materials with higher storage capacity and of greater chemical use.

Our research program combines air-sensitive inorganic synthesis and small molecule activation using some of the most electropositive metals possessing metal-ligand multiple bonds. Students and postdocs are often expose odd electron species which require extraordinary characterization methods including understanding their intrinsic properties such as electronic structure and bonding. We are one of the few synthetic groups that can transform volatile alkanes like methane into more “value-added” products such as an olefin under mild conditions and using a base metal such as titanium. Personnel in my group learn and teach the intrinsic details behind air-sensitive chemistry and are comfortable manipulating gases even under higher pressures and temperatures. Personnel in my research group are exposed to rigorous synthetic chemical training since they work with some of the most air-sensitive transition metals. Personnel are also exposed to kinetics and theory, as well as specialized techniques including the applications of some of these systems to catalytic reactions. During this funded period, the PI and personnel bridged fundamental chemistry with applied chemistry and share some of the broader aspects not only to the Penn community but also to our broader community (specially children in the 8-15 range) through chemical demonstrations. In addition to training Ph.D. students and postdocs in hydrocarbon chemistry, the PI has volunteered at ACS in the division of minority affairs, the ACS scholars’ and expert’s program, and has promoted diversity at the university level via his new role as graduate chair in the chemistry department. The PI is a member of the diversity, equity and inclusion committee of the chemistry department at the University of Pennsylvania and is making changes in recruiting to increase diversity in low-income background students, first-generation college students, URM, and diamonds-in-the-rough.
